channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Boston Perl Mongers Online Meeting - topic TBD
item.description: Tuesday February 8th, 2021 07:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 150
item.description: Simon keep it short and simple. I find it to the point discussion.Thanks for sharing.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 150: Square-Free Words
item.description: Are you Ruby fan? Roger shared his Ruby solution in this week blog, easy to follow format as always. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Fibo, nacci, Fibonacci, nacciFibonacci, FibonaccinacciFibonacci ...
item.description: I simply loved the blog title, very unique. Peter frank discussion in the blog is worth reading, you don't want to miss it.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 150
item.description: Luis is master of one-liner. This week also we got another masterpiece. Thank you.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 150: Fibonacci and squares (again!)
item.description: I loved the parameter checking in Raku. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 150: Fibonacci Words and Square Free Integers
item.description: Laurent presented us lots of new Raku magic. Perl solution is not far behind either. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #150
item.description: James keeping the tradition of compact solution. Loved the Fibonacci Words solution. Keep it up great work.

item.title: PWC150 - Square-free Integer
item.description: Once again lots of pretty Raku code, easy to follow. Cool promotion of the language. Thank you.

item.title: PWC150 - Fibonacci Words
item.description: I love Raku class. Lots of Raku magic presented in the blog. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Free The Squares!: The Weekly Challenge #150
item.description: Breaking down task into smaller sub task makes it easy to code. Difficult task appears simple. Great work.

item.title: No Squares Allowed
item.description: The background story makes an interesting read as always the case. Highly recommended.

item.title: The 51st Little Piece of String
item.description: Task specific blog gives us plenty to talk about. Colin control over the language is top notch. I am a very big fan. Thank you for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: TWC 150: bAbAbbAb and a few Composites
item.description: Cool blog title and nice compact short blog.

item.title: Fibonacci Squared Again with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne Raku solution has plenty for everyone. I loved the use of 'subset'. It makes the code cleaner and easy to read.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 150: Square-free Integer
item.description: Classic one-liner in Perl by Abigail is top class. It should be kept safe not to be lost.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 150: Fibonacci Words
item.description: Abigail special touch in this week solution using regex. You don't want to miss it.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 146
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 150
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Fibonacci Words" and "Square-free Integer" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 151
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Binary Tree Depth" and "Rob The House". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Annual Report - 2021
item.description: My annual report, little late though.

item.title: Augmenting Exporter
item.description: Flavio shared widely discussed topic 'import' and how he visualises the feature.

item.title: My Favorite Modules: re
item.description: Tom sharing his favourite module 're' dealing with Perl regex.

item.title: ProtoWebz
item.description: A very short and sweet introduction to ProtoWebz

item.title: Test web API's with Perl and Cucumber
item.description: A very interesting introduction to Behaviour-Driven development.

item.title: The difficult road to Perl
item.description: Tib sharing his journey to Perl and all the wonderful bits in between.

item.title: Perl Workflow v1.58
item.description: Jonas shared the maintenance release of Perl workflow.

item.title: Perl 5.34 transition underway
item.description: Niko uploaded Perl 5.34 to Debian unstable.

item.title: #550 - Perl & Unicode
item.description:
Hi there

Are you Unicode fan?

Personally, I am not. Reason, I still struggle to get my head around it. During my early days of learning, I never got the opportunity to work with Unicode. So far, I never had to extensively deal with Unicode characters. There is so much information available on internet. I remember, long time ago, I was dealing with well known warning Wide character in print. After a quick search, I came across this thread by Dave Cross. I have kept it bookmark for future reference. I am repeating myself as I remember talking about in the weekly newsletter earlier. It is worth sharing with the readers again and again.

However, there is another reason why I am talking about it today. Let me share gem of an article by David Cantrell. The article gives us inside out knowledge about Unicode, specially for a Perl developer. It has cleared most of my doubts, so a big thanks to David for such a great article. It also introduced me to a new word, Mojibake. A friend of mine on Facebook, suggested a CPAN module, Test::Mojibake which is very handy. I wish there was dedicated book on Perl and Unicode. Having said, I found this Wikibook on the subject, you may want to explore.

I came across YouTube video that explains the Unicode in general that any layman can easily understand as well. I loved it the way it is explain in a casual way. The guy in the video makes it so simple.

Let's talk about regex in Perl.

I am sure you have used regex in Perl at some point in your career. Few days ago, I found out a clever piece of regex shared by Abigail. The use of //g in list context. It completely blown me away. Later someone pointed me to the official Perl documentation talking about it. If you are curious to know more about it then I would suggest you please take a look at his blog post.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
